title: What is a defining characteristic of thermoplastics?
options: They soften when heated and harden when cooled
They form irreversible chemical bonds during curing
They decompose upon heating and do not reform
They always have a crystalline structure
explanation: Thermoplastics become pliable or moldable at elevated temperatures and solidify when cooled.

title: What is the main difference between thermoplastics and thermosetting polymers?
options: Thermosets form irreversible chemical bonds during curing
Thermosets can be reshaped by heating
explanation: Thermosets form irreversible chemical bonds and cannot be remelted.

title: Plastic automobile parts would crack in cold temperatures before what technique was employed?
explanation: Plasticizers and copolymerization lowered the glass transition temperature and reduced brittleness.

title: What property makes acrylic (PMMA) a substitute for glass in many products?
explanation: PMMA is known for its clarity and is used as a substitute for glass.

title: What is ABS mainly known for?
explanation: ABS is valued for its impact resistance and toughness.

title: What are the primary uses of nylon fibers?
explanation: Nylon fibers are used in fabrics, ropes, carpets, and musical strings.

title: Which thermoplastic is derived from renewable resources and widely used in 3D printing?
explanation: PLA is derived from renewable resources and is common in 3D printing.

title: A primary application for polybenzimidazole (PBI) fiber is:
options: Protective clothing for firefighters and astronauts
explanation: Polybenzimidazole is used in high-performance protective apparel.

title: Polycarbonate is known for being easily molded and worked, and is used in:
explanation: Polycarbonates are molded for electronics, aircraft parts, and more.

title: Polycarbonate items can be affected by which environmental factor, leading to yellowing?
explanation: Exposure to UV light leads to yellowing of polycarbonate.

title: Which polymer is known as acetal or polyformaldehyde?
explanation: Polyoxymethylene is also called acetal or polyformaldehyde.

title: Which characteristic is NOT associated with polyether ether ketone (PEEK)?
explanation: PEEK is known for low flammability, not high.

title: What are polyetherimides (PEI) typically used for?
options: High performance electrical and electronic parts
explanation: PEI is used in high performance electronics and automotive parts.

title: What is a common application of ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene (UHMWPE)?
explanation: UHMWPE is used for tough applications like bearings and some bulletproof vests.

title: Which type of polyethylene is most commonly used for milk jugs and detergent bottles?
explanation: HDPE is commonly used for these products.

title: What is the trade name of a blend of polyphenylene oxide (PPO) and high-impact polystyrene (HIPS)?
explanation: Noryl is a blend of PPO and HIPS for easier processing.

title: Polyphenylene sulfide (PPS) is BEST known for which property?
explanation: PPS is notable for its resistance to chemicals and flame.

title: Which thermoplastic is recyclable and commonly labeled as plastic number 5?
explanation: PP is recyclable as plastic number 5.

title: Which property is a disadvantage of polypropylene (PP)?
options: It is resistant to acids and bases
It is vulnerable to ultraviolet radiation and can degrade in direct sunlight
It is totally impermeable to gases
explanation: UV exposure causes polypropylene to degrade.

title: What is expanded polystyrene foam (EPS) commonly used for?
explanation: EPS is commonly used for insulation and packaging.

title: Flexible PVC is especially used for which type of product?
explanation: Addition of plasticizers makes PVC suitable for hoses and insulation.

title: What purpose does chlorination serve in CPVC, compared to standard PVC?
options: It increases chemical durability and heat resistance
explanation: Chlorination increases CPVC's resistance to chemicals and heat.

title: Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) is classified as a:
explanation: PVDF belongs to the fluoropolymer class.

title: What feature makes polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE, Teflon) particularly suitable for cookware coatings?
options: It has a high friction coefficient
It is hydrophobic with low surface energy
explanation: PTFE's hydrophobicity and low friction make it ideal for cookware.

title: Which statement is true regarding thermoplastic composites (TPCs)?
options: They can't be recycled once shaped
They have a high strength-to-weight ratio and are widely used in aerospace
They can only be shaped once
explanation: TPCs are prized for recyclability and use in aerospace.

title: What is the commercially common name for poly(methyl methacrylate)?
explanation: PMMA is often referred to as Plexiglas.

title: Which polyolefin is highly flexible and used for squeeze bottles and retail store bags?
explanation: LDPE is used for its flexibility in bottles and bags.

title: The clarity of a thermoplastic is often associated with:
explanation: Amorphous thermoplastics tend to be clearer because crystallinity scatters light.

title: Which of the following is a disadvantage of amorphous plastics?
explanation: They have lower chemical resistance due to lack of crystallinity.

title: Which of these is an application for polyoxymethylene (POM)?
options: Precision parts requiring high stiffness and dimensional stability
explanation: POM is used in high precision parts due to its properties.

title: Polystyrene (PS) is commonly used to manufacture:
explanation: PS is used for cutlery and insulation foam.

title: Which type of polyethylene is especially tough and used in bulletproof vests?
explanation: UHMWPE is used for bulletproof vests and tough parts.

title: Which property of plasticizers is critical in modifying thermoplastics?
options: They lower the glass transition temperature
They make plastics more flame resistant
explanation: Plasticizers lower Tg and improve flexibility.

title: Which country is NOT listed as a major PMMA market player?
explanation: Major players listed are in Japan, Germany, and France, not China.

title: A key feature of PEEK making it valuable in engineering applications is:
options: Low emission of smoke and toxic gases
explanation: PEEK is noted for low emissions and good properties at high temps.

title: What does the addition of non-reactive side chains to monomers do?
explanation: It lowers the glass transition temperature.

title: What engineering polymer is commonly used for gears and machine screws due to its stiffness?
explanation: POM is well-known as a stiff engineering polymer.

title: Which engineering thermoplastic can resist oxidative and hydrolytic degradation at elevated temperatures?
explanation: Polyether sulfone is stable under such conditions.

title: Which thermoplastic is widely used in flexible tubing, jackets, and pool toys after addition of plasticizers?
explanation: Flexible PVC is used after plasticizers are added.

title: Why are thermoplastic composites favored for aerospace applications?
options: They can be melted and reshaped multiple times
explanation: Thermoplastic composites can be remelted, reshaped, and are strong yet lightweight.

title: What is unique about thermoplastic elastomers compared to most elastomers?
options: They cure into an irreversible network
explanation: Unlike most elastomers, thermoplastic elastomers are not thermoset polymers.

title: What critical structural factor imparts high elastic properties to elastomers?
explanation: Crosslinking is key to high elastic properties in elastomers.

title: What does the abbreviation 'TPS' indicate in TPE classifications according to ISO 18064?
explanation: TPS means styrenic block copolymers.

title: Which of these is an example of a thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU)?
explanation: Texin is a thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU).

title: Which of these is a block copolymer TPE example?
explanation: CAWITON is a block copolymer TPE.

title: What is required for a material to qualify as a thermoplastic elastomer?
options: It must be able to be processed as a melt at elevated temperature
explanation: Processability as a melt is one of the three essential criteria for TPE.

title: Which of the following is NOT a criteria for a thermoplastic elastomer?
options: Can be processed as a melt
explanation: Being crystalline is not necessary for a TPE.

title: Which statement best describes the main processing advantage of thermoplastic elastomers compared to thermosets?
options: TPEs can be processed using conventional thermoplastic equipment like injection molding
TPEs must be vulcanized after molding
explanation: TPEs can be processed with standard plastic processing equipment.

title: Which method is seldom, if ever, used for manufacturing TPEs?
explanation: Compression molding is rarely used for TPEs.

title: One advantage of TPEs over conventional rubbers is that:
options: They are thermosets and thus more heat-resistant
They can be recycled after use
They must be compounded with stabilizers
explanation: TPEs can be recycled, unlike thermoset rubbers.

title: The principal difference between thermoset elastomers and TPEs lies in:
options: The type of cross-linking bond in their structures
explanation: The cross-linking type distinguishes thermosets from TPEs.

title: Which process allows TPEs to be rapidly fabricated and is highly economical?
explanation: Injection molding is rapid and economical for TPEs.

title: Which of the following TPEs is used for shoe soles and adhesives?
explanation: Kraton (SBS block copolymer) is used for shoe soles and adhesives.

title: Which of these is NOT a generic class of commercial TPEs?
explanation: PVC is not considered a generic class of TPE.

title: Which is an example of a TPO compound?
explanation: Engage is an example of a TPO.

title: The microphase separation in block copolymers such as SBS is due to:
options: Incompatibility between blocks leading to distinct domains
explanation: Microphase separation arises from block incompatibility.

title: Which technique is used to confirm the spacing between domains in block copolymers?
explanation: Small-angle X-ray scattering provides microstructure details.

title: What property gives TPEs a longer life and better physical range than other materials?
options: Ability to stretch and return to original shape
explanation: Elastic recovery gives TPEs enhanced longevity and performance.

title: Which statement is true for TPE processing?
options: TPEs can be processed via extrusion, injection molding, blow molding, and 3D printing
TPEs must be chemically cured post-shaping
explanation: TPEs are compatible with all these processing techniques.

title: Which polymer is an exception to the usual incompatibility of polymers in block copolymers?
explanation: Noryl uniquely blends polystyrene and PPO.

title: Which TPE is used mainly in snowmobile tracks for stiffness and abrasion resistance?
explanation: Copolyester TPEs (TPC) offer high stiffness/abrasion resistance.

title: What is the function of osmium tetroxide in TEM imaging of block copolymer microstructure?
options: It stains the butadiene matrix for contrast
explanation: Osmium tetroxide enhances contrast of butadiene in TEM imaging.

title: Which application area has seen increased use of thermoplastic olefins (TPO)?
explanation: TPOs are gaining popularity as roofing materials.

title: What is one primary benefit of batch-to-batch consistency in TPE manufacturing?
explanation: Consistency in batches improves overall product quality.

title: Which component is typically NOT needed in TPE compounding?
explanation: Cross-linking agents are typically not required for TPEs.

title: The main reason TPEs can be recycled is because they:
explanation: TPEs' thermoplastic nature allows melting and reprocessing.

title: Which property of TPEs makes them especially useful for soft-grip surfaces?
explanation: Their elastomeric nature enables soft, grippy surfaces.

title: Which statement about TPEs and energy consumption is true?
options: TPEs consume more energy to produce than conventional rubbers
TPEs consume less energy to produce
TPEs require none of the typical processing steps
TPEs can only be processed by hand
explanation: TPEs are more energy-efficient than many alternatives.

title: Which of the following TPEs is noted for medical and consumer product uses?
explanation: THERMOLAST K is widely used in medical/consumer applications.

title: Why does living polymerization help in producing regular microstructures in block copolymers?
options: It introduces many different chain lengths
It leads to almost monodisperse chain lengths
explanation: Monodisperse chains help regular nanostructure formation.

title: Which class of TPEs is known for their use as catheters for their softness?
explanation: TPA/nylon block copolymers are ideal for soft catheters.

title: What broad technical advantage do TPEs offer for HVAC industry applications?
explanation: TPEs' cost effectiveness and design adaptability boost HVAC use.

title: Which application makes use of 3D printed TPEs?
explanation: TPEs can be printed as flexible filaments for various objects.

title: Which manufacturing method is most rarely used for thermoplastic elastomers?
explanation: Compression molding is seldom used for TPEs.

title: How does batch-to-batch consistency in TPEs affect quality control?
options: It makes quality control more difficult
It is not relevant to quality control
It simplifies and improves quality control
It requires manual inspection for every batch
explanation: High consistency improves and automates quality control.

title: Which of these products would most likely use thermoplastic vulcanizates (TPV)?
explanation: TPVs are used in car weatherstripping for flexibility and durability.

title: Why can TPEs be colored easily?
options: They process as melts which allow colors to be mixed uniformly
They must be colored after fabrication
explanation: Their melt processing enables easy addition of colorants.

title: What is a primary application for engineered TPS materials?
options: Back-lit switches and soft design elements
explanation: Engineered TPS is used for soft grip and design features.

title: What determines the processing temperatures and service-use limits for crystalline TPEs?
explanation: Crystal melting point controls TPE processing/service temperature.

title: For what reason are TPE bushings used in automotive performance applications?
options: Greater resistance to deformation vs. regular rubber
Lower cost than all other bushings
explanation: TPE bushings resist deformation better than typical rubber bushings.

title: What is the main purpose of catheter ablation?
options: To destroy faulty electrical pathways in the heart
To improve blood flow through blocked arteries
explanation: Catheter ablation targets and destroys areas in the heart causing abnormal electrical signals.

title: Which energy sources are most commonly used for catheter ablation?
explanation: Radiofrequency and cryoablation are the primary energy sources for catheter ablation.

title: What type of arrhythmia can be specifically treated by pulmonary vein isolation?
explanation: Pulmonary vein isolation is particularly used to treat atrial fibrillation.

title: Which statement about Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome treatment with ablation is correct?
options: It has shown limited effectiveness in clinical studies
Success rates are as high as 95%
It is only recommended after multiple failed drug therapies
It cannot be treated by catheter ablation
explanation: Ablation has success rates as high as 95% for WPW syndrome.

title: For supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), what is the approximate range for success after a single catheter ablation procedure?
explanation: Single procedure success is between 91% and 96%.

title: Why might older patients with chronic atrial fibrillation have lower ablation success rates?
options: Their heart has often undergone atrial remodeling
They are more likely to have valve disease
explanation: Atrial remodeling in older patients makes ablation less effective.

title: What is a possible complication of catheter ablation?
explanation: Blood clots can form and potentially lead to embolism.

title: What is the function of electrodes at the tip of cardiac catheters during ablation?
options: To monitor and map electrical signals
explanation: Electrodes measure the heart's electrical activity to identify arrhythmia sources.

title: Which vein is NOT commonly used for advancing catheters during ablation?
explanation: The radial vein is not typically used; the others are common access sites.

title: What distinguishes electroporation from other ablation techniques?
options: It kills tissue using high-voltage electrical pulses with better selectivity
explanation: Electroporation forms irreversible pores, selectively killing cardiac muscle cells.

title: After completion of a catheter ablation, the patient is not allowed to move for several hours primarily to:
options: Reduce the risk of blood vessel damage and bleeding
Allow the ablated tissue to heal
Give anesthesia time to wear off
explanation: Movement could lead to bleeding from the catheter insertion site.

title: Which cardiac procedure is sometimes performed when standard catheter ablation fails?
explanation: Epicardial ablation is an option if endocardial ablation is unsuccessful.

title: During epicardial ablation, access to the pericardial space is achieved via:
explanation: The subxiphoid region provides the safest route to the pericardial space.

title: The 'blanking period' after catheter ablation refers to:
options: The time required for anesthesia recovery
The first three months post-ablation when arrhythmia recurrence does not indicate procedure failure
A medication-free interval before antiarrhythmic therapy is restarted
explanation: The blanking period is three months where early recurrences do not count as failure.

title: Why is the blanking period sometimes considered too long?
options: It does not allow for proper tissue healing
Most arrhythmia recurrences occur within the first month
It restricts physical activity for too long
explanation: Research suggests most early recurrences happen within the first month, not three months.

title: What is the likelihood of recurrence during the nine months following the blanking period?
explanation: Recurrence rates can range from 25% to 40% post-blanking period.

title: After ablation, how many patients typically continue on antiarrhythmic medications?
explanation: About 30-40% of patients require continued medication after ablation.

title: Which best describes the general safety profile of catheter ablation?
options: It is highly risky with a complication rate above 50%
It is considered safe and minimally invasive
It is recommended only as a last resort
It is safer than all medical therapies
explanation: The procedure is generally safe and minimally invasive.

title: Which of the following is NOT a potential complication of catheter ablation?
explanation: Chronic kidney disease is not a listed complication of ablation.

title: Which arrhythmia is abbreviated ERAT in the medical literature?
options: Early recurrence of atrial arrhythmias after ablation
explanation: ERAT stands for early recurrence of atrial arrhythmias post-ablation.

title: How are ablation catheters typically delivered to the heart?
options: Through a blood vessel, such as the femoral vein
explanation: Catheters are inserted through veins like the femoral vein and advanced to the heart.

title: Which statement about early recurrences of atrial arrhythmias (ERAT) after ablation is true?
options: They are temporary and often resolve without intervention
They indicate immediate need for surgery
They are caused by structural heart disease only
explanation: ERAT is often transient and does not necessarily mean the ablation failed.

title: What is the main risk if large amounts of fluid accumulate around the heart after ablation?
explanation: Cardiac tamponade is a dangerous accumulation of fluid around the heart.

title: Which best describes the use of antiarrhythmic drugs after ablation?
options: They are sometimes used to prevent early recurrences
All patients must use them for life
They replace the need for ablation
explanation: Antiarrhythmics are often used short-term post-ablation to prevent early recurrences.

title: What is a recognized benefit of catheter ablation for atrial fibrillation?
options: Eliminates the risk of all future arrhythmias
Improves quality of life and mental health outcomes
Removes the need for any medical follow-up
Guarantees lifelong sinus rhythm after one procedure
explanation: Ablation can improve quality of life and mental health outcomes.

title: What success rate was reported for ablation of premature ventricular contraction in a 2018 study?
explanation: Efficacy of cardiac ablation for premature ventricular contraction was 94.1%.

title: Which technique is stated to be more effective at preventing recurrent atrial arrhythmias, but is technically more difficult?
explanation: Bipolar ablation is more effective, but harder to perform.

title: In the context of catheter ablation, what is the most common outcome regarding tissue edema?
explanation: Tissue edema after ablation usually resolves in one month.

title: Which of the following is NOT a usual step in epicardial ablation?
options: Insertion of a wire and then a plastic tube
Catheter insertion through the subxiphoid region
explanation: Direct biopsy is not a standard part of epicardial ablation technique.

title: Why is movement minimized after a catheter ablation procedure?
options: To prevent damage to the pulmonary veins
To reduce bleeding from the catheter insertion site
To allow electrical pathways to heal
To enhance the effects of anesthesia
explanation: Minimizing movement prevents bleeding at the puncture site.

title: What is the typical complication rate for cardiac ablation procedures according to studies?
explanation: Overall complication rates are about 6%.

title: Which of these is a potential benefit of pulmonary vein isolation for atrial fibrillation patients?
options: Permanent elimination of coronary artery disease
Higher quality of life at 12 months post-treatment
explanation: Pulmonary vein isolation is more effective than drug therapy for improving quality of life at 12 months.

title: Catheter ablation is often performed in which hospital setting?
explanation: Ablation procedures are usually done in the cath lab.

title: What leads to the need for multiple ablation procedures in atrial fibrillation patients?
options: Progressive atrial remodeling making correction more difficult
explanation: Atrial remodeling in longstanding AF often requires multiple procedures for success.

title: What has been reported regarding relapse after ERAT?
options: Half of patients with symptomatic ERAT will relapse
All patients relapse after one year
Relapse occurs only in patients with diabetes
explanation: Half of symptomatic ERAT cases will relapse.

title: What type of lesion is created by original DC impulse ablation?
options: An electrical burn in the conduction system
explanation: The DC impulse creates an electrical lesion but was abandoned due to complications.

title: What main factor affects recurrence rates after the blanking period?
options: Obesity and severity of AF before ablation
explanation: Obesity and prior AF severity influence post-blanking recurrence rates.

title: Ablation is considered most effective in which group of atrial fibrillation patients?
options: Elderly patients with chronic atrial fibrillation
explanation: Paroxysmal, younger AF patients have the best ablation outcomes.

title: What is the main use of ablation in arrhythmia management?
options: Modification or destruction of problematic cardiac tissue
explanation: Ablation modifies or destroys the tissue causing arrhythmias.

title: Which of the following can sometimes be left in place after epicardial ablation to prevent fluid buildup?
explanation: A small plastic tube (drain) may be used to remove pericardial fluid.

title: What is the primary goal of electroanatomic mapping in cardiac electrophysiology?
options: To create a 3D map of the heart and guide catheter placement
To replace heart valves by surgical means
explanation: Electroanatomic mapping aims to reconstruct the heart's 3D model to guide catheters and reduce fluoroscopy.

title: What technology does Carto primarily use for catheter localization?
options: Low-intensity magnetic fields and tri-axial inductors
explanation: Carto uses low-intensity magnetic fields and tri-axial inductors at the catheter tip.

title: What technique used by EnSite maps catheter position?
options: Induced electric fields and impedance measurements
explanation: EnSite uses induced electric fields (in 3 axes) and impedance to localize catheters.

title: Which system utilizes both impedance and magnetic fields for mapping?
explanation: Rhythmia employs both impedance and magnetic field techniques for accurate catheter mapping.

title: Which is NOT one of the three main types of data generated by mapping systems?
explanation: The main types are geometry, voltage, and timing (LAT) maps; 'electrical geometry' is not a standard type.

title: What is a key advantage of using electroanatomic mapping during ablation?
options: It eliminates the need for general anesthesia
It reduces the need for fluoroscopy and thus radiation exposure
It increases the cost of the operation
explanation: Real-time visualization reduces reliance on fluoroscopy and decreases radiation exposure.

title: Which mapping system is developed by Boston Scientific?
explanation: Rhythmia, now also called Opal, is developed by Boston Scientific.

title: Which system allows speedy mapping with better accuracy for treating rhythm disturbances?
explanation: EnSite Precision, by Abbott, enables fast and accurate heart mapping.

title: Which company produces the Carto mapping system?
options: Biosense-Webster, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson
explanation: Carto is developed by Biosense-Webster, part of J&J.

title: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the navigation of the Carto system?
options: It requires the patient to remain awake
It calculates catheter tip position and orientation using magnetic sources
It can only calculate position if the catheter is moving
explanation: Carto's system calculates both position and orientation via calibrated magnetic fields.

title: Which professional is recognized as the father of interventional cardiology?
explanation: Andreas Gruentzig is considered the father of interventional cardiology.

title: What is the primary purpose of interventional cardiology procedures?
options: Catheter-based treatment of structural heart diseases
explanation: Interventional cardiology focuses on catheter-based structural heart disease treatments.

title: Which artery is MOST commonly used for catheterization in interventional cardiology?
explanation: The femoral artery is traditionally the main access site.

title: Which access site is gaining popularity due to patient comfort and rapid mobilization post-procedure?
explanation: Radial artery access enables quicker patient mobilization.

title: A potential complication unique to the radial approach is:
explanation: Radial access may result in arterial spasm and discomfort.

title: What defines 'pin-hole surgery' in interventional cardiology?
options: Making a small hole in an artery for device delivery
explanation: 'Pin-hole surgery' refers to using very small arterial access for interventions.

title: What is the principal benefit of interventional as opposed to open-heart procedures?
options: Avoidance of scars, pain, and long recovery
explanation: Interventional procedures avoid large incisions, reduce pain, and speed recovery.

title: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is also known as:
explanation: PCI refers to coronary angioplasty.

title: What is the role of a balloon catheter during PCI?
options: To inflate within the artery and relieve narrowing
explanation: A balloon is inflated to dilate the narrowed artery.

title: Which device may be deployed during PCI to help keep blood vessels open?
explanation: A stent can be placed during angioplasty to maintain vessel patency.

title: What is the preferred treatment for acute myocardial infarction?
explanation: Primary angioplasty is currently the gold standard.

title: Complete revascularization has been shown to be superior to culprit-only vessel PCI in what way?
options: Reducing major adverse cardiac events and all-cause mortality
Decreasing the amount of anesthesia needed
explanation: Complete revascularization reduces adverse events and mortality rates.

title: Percutaneous valve replacement is an alternative to what procedure?
explanation: It's performed instead of open-heart replacement.

title: The TAVI procedure is related to what type of valve?
explanation: TAVI stands for transcatheter aortic valve implantation.

title: For percutaneous mitral valve repair, which device is used?
explanation: MitraClip is a device for percutaneous mitral repair.

title: Coronary thrombectomy is performed to:
options: Remove blood clots from coronary arteries
explanation: Coronary thrombectomy is the removal of thrombosis (clots) from coronaries.

title: Open heart surgeries are performed by whom?
explanation: Cardiothoracic surgeons are trained for open-heart surgeries.

title: Which statement BEST describes education required for interventional cardiology in the US?
options: Four years of post-medical school training
At least seven to nine years of post-graduate education
explanation: It requires a minimum of 79 years of postgraduate medical training.

title: A typical pathway for a structural heart intervention specialist requires training in which order?
options: Medical school, cardiology fellowship, structural heart intervention fellowship
Undergraduate, medical school, internal medicine, cardiology fellowship, interventional, then structural heart fellowship
explanation: A typical sequence includes undergrad, med school, internal med, cardiology, interventional, and structural fellowships.

title: Which access site provides easiest control of post-procedural bleeding, according to the text?
explanation: Radial artery access offers easy bleeding control after the procedure.

title: Which is NOT an advantage of the radial approach?
options: Immediate ability to walk after procedure
Near absence of severe sequelae with normal Allen test
explanation: Large catheters cannot be used via radial, which is a disadvantage.

title: What is a geometry map in electroanatomic mapping?
options: A 3D structural representation of the heart chamber
explanation: Geometry maps represent the 3D spatial structure of heart chambers.

title: What does a voltage map in cardiac mapping illustrate?
options: Differences in the amplitude of electrical signals
explanation: Voltage maps display variations in electrical signal amplitude across the heart.

title: A timing or LAT map provides what kind of data?
options: Relative timing of electrogram recordings at various locations
explanation: It indicates the local activation times across different heart regions.

title: Which of the following is a use of percutaneous valve REPLACEMENT?
explanation: Percutaneous valve replacement provides a non-surgical option for treating stenotic valves.

title: Which of these is TRUE about percutaneous valve REPAIR?
options: Can be performed using devices like MitraClip
Can only be done on aortic valves
explanation: Devices like MitraClip are used for percutaneous mitral valve repair.

title: Who developed angioplasty before Gruentzigs widespread adaptation?
explanation: Charles Dotter, an interventional radiologist, first developed angioplasty.

title: Which advantage is associated with interventional cardiology procedures?
explanation: Reduced scarring and pain is a significant advantage.

title: Which system operates with static, calibrated, and computer-controlled magnetic fields?
explanation: Carto uses static, computer-calibrated magnetic fields for mapping.

title: Which intervention involves closure of a patients ductus arteriosus?
explanation: Percutaneous methods can correct congenital issues like patent ductus arteriosus.

title: What is a primary advantage of using robotic systems in minimally invasive surgery?
options: Enhanced precision and dexterity for the surgeon
Lower equipment costs compared to traditional surgery
Ability to perform surgery without any human involvement
explanation: Robotics overcome limitations of human hands, improving precision and dexterity during minimally invasive surgeries.

title: What feature distinguishes a telemanipulator system in robotic surgery?
options: Allows the surgeon to remotely control surgical instruments in real time
Removes the need for a surgical assistant
explanation: A telemanipulator enables real-time remote control by the surgeon.

title: The main advantage of computer-controlled surgical systems is:
options: They can be operated entirely by nurses
They allow strategies such as remote surgery and potential AI assistance
They eliminate the need for sterilization
They are less expensive than manual procedures
explanation: Computer-controlled systems potentially allow remote and AI-assisted surgeries.

title: What was the worlds first robot to assist in surgery?
explanation: Arthrobot, developed in Vancouver in 1983, was the first surgical robot.

title: What key role did the Unimation Puma 200 robotic arm perform in 1985?
options: Needle orientation for brain biopsy under CT guidance
explanation: It oriented needles for brain biopsies with CT guidance.

title: Which robotic system is known for enabling telerobotics or telepresence surgery?
explanation: ZEUS was known for telepresence surgery, where procedures are done remotely.

title: What is the function of the AESOP robotic system in surgery?
options: Holding and positioning a laparoscopic camera under surgeon control
explanation: AESOP was designed to hold and position the laparoscopic camera.

title: Which surgical procedure was first completed remotely with the ZEUS surgical system?
explanation: The Lindbergh Operation, a cholecystectomy, was performed remotely using ZEUS.

title: Compared to ZEUS, what key feature does the da Vinci robotic system offer?
options: Ability to mimic the human wrist
explanation: The da Vinci can mimic the human wrist, enhancing movement range.

title: Which system allows surgeons to perform complex surgical procedures with high accuracy and control?
explanation: The da Vinci Surgical System is renowned for high accuracy and control.

title: What was the main purpose of ROBODOC in orthopedic surgery?
options: Assisting with hip replacements by milling femoral bone
explanation: ROBODOC was designed to mill out bone for precise hip implant fitting.

title: In robotic surgery, what is a major benefit of using stereoscopic vision for the surgeon?
options: Three-dimensional, high-precision view of the surgical field
explanation: Stereoscopic vision provides a 3D perspective, improving surgical accuracy.

title: Which feature does NOT currently characterize most clinical robotic surgical systems?
options: Fully autonomous operation without surgeon input
explanation: Most robotic systems are not fully autonomous; they are surgeon-controlled.

title: What is the main drawback of robotic surgery mentioned regarding training?
options: Intensive learning phase, requiring 150250 procedures before proficiency
It costs less to operate than traditional surgery
explanation: Robotic systems require intensive training and many practice cases.

title: Which robotic system has been specifically developed for supermicrosurgical tasks in plastic and reconstructive surgery?
explanation: MUSA was developed for microsurgery and supermicrosurgery.

title: What is a unique advantage of robotic-assisted heart surgery systems?
options: Allows surgery to be performed remotely and minimally invasively
explanation: Robotic heart surgery can be minimally invasive and may even be performed remotely.

title: In robotic ENT (Ear, Nose, Throat) surgery, one main benefit of robot-assisted cochlear implantation is:
options: Improved accuracy leading to fewer mistakes in electrode insertion
explanation: Robots provide greater accuracy with fewer insertion errors.

title: What was the significance of the 2017 autonomous dental implant procedure in China?
options: It was the first dental robot to be FDA approved
It was the world's first successful autonomous dental surgery without human intervention
It was performed using 3D printing technology only
It resulted in a failed implant
explanation: The 2017 case in China was a breakthrough as an autonomous dental procedure.

title: Which industry was NOT an early supporter of Computer Motion, the creators of AESOP?
explanation: NASA, government agencies, and space industry were involved; automotive industry was not mentioned.

title: Which robotic system allows force feedback during surgical procedures?
explanation: Senhance system by Asensus Surgical introduced haptic feedback.

title: Compared to open or laparoscopic procedures, robotic surgery typically results in:
options: Reduced blood loss and quicker healing
explanation: Robotic surgery often means less blood loss and quicker recovery.

title: For which pediatric surgery is robotic assistance most commonly used?
explanation: Pyeloplasty is the most common robotic-assisted pediatric procedure.

title: What is a common criticism regarding the use of robotic surgery for benign gynecologic procedures in the U.S.?
options: It is much less expensive than conventional approaches
There is little difference in complication rate but greater cost
Patients have a higher survival rate
It is the only FDA-approved method
explanation: Robotic gynecologic surgery is more costly with little difference in complication rates.

title: Which factor has limited wider adoption of robotic spine surgery as of 2014?
options: High number of randomized clinical trials
Lack of proven safety over other approaches
explanation: There were too few randomized clinical trials to judge relative safety.

title: What is a long-term concern regarding robot-assisted surgery systems?
options: Mechanical failure of the system or instruments
Absolute elimination of need for anesthesia
explanation: Mechanical failures, though rare, are an ongoing concern.

title: Which is a notable characteristic of the Versius Surgical System?
options: Large, fixed unit for single positioning
Independent, modular arms and flexible setup
explanation: Versius features modular independent arms and flexible configuration.

title: What is a limitation of current single-quadrant robotic surgery systems?
options: They cannot be used for abdominal surgery
Only trained nurses may operate them
They are mainly useful for procedures in one abdominal region at a time
explanation: Most current systems are limited to single-quadrant procedures.

title: Which surgical specialty experienced the first fully robotic lung transplantation?
explanation: Robotic lung transplantation is part of thoracic surgery.

title: How does robotic technology especially benefit pediatric surgery?
options: Allows clearer viewing and better instrument control in small spaces
explanation: Smaller patients limit viewing; robotic systems enhance visualization and precision.

title: What is a distinctive feature of robotic hernia surgery compared to laparoscopic methods?
options: Allows complex reconstructions traditionally limited to open surgery
explanation: The robotic approach allows for repairs traditionally only done via open surgery.

title: What enables the robotic system to minimize naturally occurring hand tremors in surgery?
explanation: The robotic system electronically filters out hand tremors.

title: What is a frequent patient motivation for choosing robot-assisted procedures?
options: Expectation of improved outcomes and less pain
explanation: Patients hope for improved recovery and less morbidity/pain.

title: Which robotic platform is specifically designed for natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) in gynecology?
options: Hominis robotic system by Momentis Surgical
explanation: Hominis is designed for NOTES via natural orifices in gynecology.

title: What characterizes the PRECEYES Surgical System in ophthalmology?
options: Telemanipulated by a surgeon for increased precision
explanation: PRECEYES is telemanipulated for retinal surgeries with high precision.

title: A key challenge still to be addressed in robot-assisted cochlear implantation is:
explanation: Challenges include safety, efficiency, cost, and procedure time.

title: What is a benefit of using Mazor X in spinal surgeries?
options: Improves accuracy in pedicle screw placement using templating imaging
explanation: Mazor X uses imaging to improve pedicle screw placement accuracy.

title: Which statement best describes the public perception issue regarding dental robotics?
options: There is increased curiosity and concern over shifting from traditional to robotic dental procedures
All countries ban autonomous dental robots
Robotic procedures are only used in oral cancer cases
explanation: There is a mix of curiosity and concern as robotics become more prevalent in dentistry.

title: Why is identifying culpability difficult in robot-assisted surgery?
options: Unclear distinction between surgeon and robotic system responsibility
explanation: It is often unclear if errors are due to the surgeon or the technology.

title: Which is an example of a minimally invasive approach enabled by the da Vinci Xi system?
options: Lung and mediastinal mass resection with 3D visualization
explanation: The da Vinci Xi enables 3D visualized, minimally invasive thoracic surgery.

title: What is the primary purpose of digital dental 3D modeling in robot-assisted dentistry?
options: To create accurate guides for drilling and restoration
To eliminate the need for dentists
To train patients in robotic technology
explanation: Digital models provide accurate guides for surgical planning and restoration.

title: What distinguishes CSST from FAC tubing?
options: CSST is covered by a plastic sheath, hiding the corrugations
CSST is made only in short lengths
FAC tubing is always electrically conductive
explanation: FAC tubing's corrugations are visible, but CSST's are covered by a plastic sheath.

title: Which feature is unique to FAC tubing compared to CSST?
options: It is available in black and yellow jackets
It comes with connectors on each end
It is used for distributing fuel gas throughout buildings
It always has a plastic sheath
explanation: FAC tubing is made with connectors on each end.

title: What type of CSST was developed first and is most commonly used?
explanation: Yellow-jacketed CSST was developed first and is most common.

title: What is a purpose of the black jacket on black-jacketed CSST?
options: To dissipate energy from lightning strikes
explanation: Black-jacketed CSST's conductive jacket dissipates lightning energy.

title: Which material was formerly used in older FAC tubing?
explanation: Previously, corrugated brass tubing was used for FAC.

title: What is NOT an advantage of CSST over black iron pipe?
explanation: CSST is more expensive than black iron pipe.

title: What key construction difference separates typical residential CSST from black iron gas pipe?
options: It is always made of copper
explanation: CSST is 0.20.3 mm thick; black iron is 34 mm thick.

title: What is a recommended way to reduce the risk of lightning-related CSST damage?
options: Install CSST without a plastic sheath
Always locate CSST in direct contact with metal ductwork
Bond yellow-jacketed CSST to the service panel's ground bus
explanation: Yellow-jacketed CSST should be bonded to the building's electrical ground.

title: What is a property of black-jacketed CSST according to manufacturers?
options: It requires no bonding to ground
Its black jacket is electrically conductive
It is always cheaper than yellow-jacketed CSST
explanation: Black-jacketed CSST's jacket is conductive to dissipate energy.

title: Which professional should ideally inspect CSST installation for safety and compliance?
explanation: Licensed plumbers and electricians are the experts for CSST inspections.

title: Which property is associated with stripwound metal hoses?
options: Great flexibility, but not fully leak-tight
explanation: Stripwound hoses are highly flexible but not fully leak-tight.

title: Which invention is credited to Heinrich Witzenmann and Eugne Levavassur?
options: The first stainless steel braided hose
explanation: They invented the first stripwound metal hose in 1885.

title: In manufacturing, what is a typical application of corrugated hoses?
options: As pressure- or vacuum-tight conduits for liquids or gases
As insulation sleeves for thermal blankets
explanation: Corrugated hoses are pressure/vacuum-tight conduits for liquids or gases.

title: Why are annular corrugation hoses more common than helical ones?
options: They connect more smoothly to fittings and avoid torsional damage
explanation: Annular corrugated hoses avoid torsional strain and connect more smoothly.

title: The type of motion supported by a 'swan neck' or 'bendable arm' metal hose is:
options: It bends in one direction only
It can be bent in any direction and remain in place
It can only be twisted, not bent
explanation: 'Swan necks' can be bent in any direction and remain stationary.

title: A property that distinguishes stripwound hoses from corrugated hoses is:
options: They can be made completely leak-tight without additional sheathing
They always have insulating foam inside
They are not fully leak-tight and are often used as protective hoses
They cannot be made out of steel
explanation: Stripwound hoses are not fully leak-tight and are often used as protective hoses.

title: Which of the following is true about corrugated metal hoses?
options: They are used only for decorative purposes
They are completely rigid and cannot flex
Their flexibility is due to the elastic behavior of the corrugation profile
They cannot be manufactured with a braided sheath
explanation: Corrugated hoses' flexibility comes from the elastic behavior of corrugations.

title: The flexibility and pressure resistance of a corrugated hose depend on:
options: Only the length of the hose
The profile shape and wall thickness
explanation: Profile shape and wall thickness affect flexibility and pressure resistance.

title: The first metal hose was modeled after what type of jewelry?
explanation: The first metal hose was modeled after the goose throat necklace.

title: What best describes the function of braided sheathing on a metal hose?
options: It changes the gas carried by the hose
Provides color coding for different gases
Increases pressure resistance and absorbs longitudinal forces
Adds electrical insulation to the hose
explanation: Braided sheathing increases pressure resistance and absorbs forces.

title: Which country saw the invention of the first stripwound metal hose?
explanation: Heinrich Witzenmann was German and patented it in Germany.

title: Which property is LEAST associated with metal hoses?
explanation: Compressive strength is not the standout property; tensile and chemical/thermal stability are.

title: A stripwound hose with an interlocked profile exhibits:
options: High flexibility due to the profile structure
explanation: The profile structure gives stripwound hoses their flexibility.

title: Which method creates an annular corrugated hose?
options: Hydraulic corrugation expanding the tube from inside
explanation: Hydraulic corrugation expands the tube from inside for annular hoses.

title: Why would one use a PVC or silicone sheath over a stripwound metal hose?
explanation: Sheathing improves the leak-tightness of stripwound hoses.

title: Where would you commonly find miniature stripwound hoses?
options: As lamp cord in desk lamps
explanation: Miniature stripwound hoses are used in medical technology like endoscopy.

title: How does decreasing wall thickness affect a corrugated hose?
options: Increases pressure resistance and decreases flexibility
Increases flexibility and decreases pressure resistance
explanation: Thinner walls mean more flexibility but less pressure resistance.

title: Which is NOT a typical application area for metal hoses?
explanation: Compost heaps are not a metal hose application.

title: The main principle enabling high flexibility of stripwound hoses is:
options: Movable connection between the profiled coils
explanation: Flexible structure comes from movable coil connections.

title: During corrugated hose manufacturing, what does braiding the hose accomplish?
options: It increases pressure resistance and prevents hose lengthening due to internal pressure
explanation: Braiding boosts pressure resistance and prevents hose elongation.

title: What additional feature do some metal hoses have for maximum leak-tightness?
options: Incorporation of a sealing thread like rubber or cotton
explanation: A sealing thread is added in a profiled chamber for tightness.

title: What enables metal bellows to be created?
options: Rolling annular corrugations into a tube
Twisting two hoses in opposite directions
explanation: Metal bellows are formed by rolling annular corrugations.

title: Which cross-section shape is common with stripwound metal hoses?
explanation: They can have round and various polygonal cross-sections.

title: Which mechanical property is especially pronounced in stripwound hoses?
explanation: Stripwound hoses have high torsional strength.

title: What effect does braiding have on the flexibility of a metal hose?
options: It flexibly moulds itself to the hose's movements
explanation: Braiding maintains flexibility, adapting to hose movement.

title: A miniature metal hose with special connectors can be used in which of the following areas?
explanation: Miniature hoses are used in optoelectronic and laser applications.

title: Which operating condition is a metal hose particularly designed to resist?
explanation: Metal hoses have corrosion resistance, even in aggressive seawater.

title: Which element is essential to increase the resistance of a hose to internal pressure?
explanation: Using one or two layers of braid increases pressure resistance.

title: When compressing a braided metal hose axially, what changes?
options: The crossing angle and diameter increase
explanation: Axial compression increases the crossing angle and the braid diameter.

title: In what scenario should CSST not be installed to avoid leaks?
options: Where cabinet screws or nails might pierce it
Where it is bonded to ground
Away from all other metal piping
explanation: Avoid placing CSST where objects could pierce it.

title: What is the process of inserting a catheter called?
explanation: The process of inserting a catheter is called catheterization.

title: Which material is commonly used for implantable catheters due to its inertness?
explanation: Silicone is commonly used for implantable catheters because it is inert and unreactive.

title: A catheter left in the body for a long time is commonly called a(n):
explanation: Indwelling catheter refers to one left in the body temporarily or permanently.

title: The earliest flexible catheter was invented by which historical figure?
explanation: Benjamin Franklin invented the flexible catheter in 1752.

title: Which of the following is NOT a primary indication for indwelling urinary catheter use?
options: Monitoring urine output in critically ill patients
explanation: Indwelling catheters should not be used merely for convenience.

title: Catheters used in angioplasty that have small blades to cut through stenosis are called:
explanation: Cutting balloon catheters have small blades to help with resistant stenosis.

title: Which historical procedure did Claude Bernard pioneer with catheters in 1844?
explanation: He performed cardiac catheterization in a horse in 1844.

title: Guiding catheters usually contain which innermost material for lubrication?
explanation: PTFE is used for its lubricious properties.

title: Which of the following best describes a 'three-way' urinary catheter?
options: It has two lumens for urine flow
It has one lumen and one valve
It has three lumens for irrigation, drainage, and balloon inflation
It is made only of glass
explanation: A three-way catheter has lumens for irrigation, drainage, and balloon inflation.

title: What color is commonly associated with a 22 French unit urinary catheter?
explanation: Purple is typically associated with 22 Fr catheters.

title: What is the most common hospital-acquired infection in the US due to catheters?
explanation: Catheter-associated UTI is the most common hospital-acquired infection.

title: Which of the following patients typically should NOT receive an indwelling urinary catheter?
options: Patient in critical care needing output monitoring
explanation: Stable patients who can urinate should not receive an indwelling catheter.

title: Urethral trauma is what type of contraindication to urinary catheter placement?
explanation: Urethral trauma is the only absolute contraindication.

title: Which design feature of the Foley catheter prevents it from slipping out of the bladder?
explanation: The inflatable balloon anchors the catheter within the bladder.

title: A pigtail catheter is used primarily for:
options: Delivering a large volume of contrast during imaging
explanation: Pigtail catheters deliver large volumes of contrast for imaging.

title: The Seldinger technique is often used to:
options: Gain access to blood vessels with a catheter
explanation: It's a standard technique for vascular access with catheters.

title: Which catheter tip is designed to navigate an enlarged prostate more easily?
explanation: Coud catheters have a bent tip for easier navigation.

title: What is a major risk of Teflon (PTFE) catheters in interventional use?
explanation: Teflon catheters have a higher risk of thrombus formation.

title: A 'permcath' refers to a catheter that is:
explanation: Permcath is a term for a permanently inserted catheter.

title: Which of the following historical events MOST contributed to the mass production of disposable catheters?
explanation: World War II disrupted the supply of French cotton catheters, spurring innovation.

title: In cases of severe epistaxis, a Foley catheter may be used to:
options: Stop blood flow through the femoral artery
Block blood from flowing down the nasal passage
explanation: Foley catheters can block nasal passages to control nosebleeds.

title: A major disadvantage of reusing red rubber catheters is:
options: Risk of infection and disease transmission
explanation: Reusable rubber catheters have a high risk of infection.

title: In the context of urine drainage, what is the primary advantage of a suprapubic catheter over a standard Foley catheter?
explanation: Suprapubic catheters are used when the urethra is damaged.

title: Which catheter coating is intended to reduce friction during insertion?
explanation: Lubricious coatings help with easier, less traumatic insertion.

title: Which invention is David S. Sheridan best known for in the context of catheters?
explanation: He invented the modern disposable plastic catheter.

title: Permcath, originally a trademarked name, refers to which of the following?
options: A permanently inserted catheter for dialysis or other uses
A research probe for lipophilic compounds
explanation: Permcath is used for permanent or long-term insertion, often for dialysis.

title: Which historical figure performed the first recorded central venous catheterization?
explanation: Werner Forssman performed the first central venous catheterization in 1929.

title: Angiography imaging through catheters often utilizes what material as a contrast agent?
explanation: Radiocontrast agents are commonly injected for imaging.

title: Which risk increases with both the size and duration of a catheter left in the body?
explanation: Thrombus formation risk increases with catheter size and duration.

title: A micro-3D-printed endovascular device is especially suited for which unique purpose?
options: Harvesting endothelial cells for transcriptomic analysis
explanation: Such devices are designed for harvesting endothelial cells for detailed analysis.

title: A balloon-tipped catheter used to ripen the cervix in labor induces dilation by:
options: Applying direct pressure to mimic baby's head
explanation: The inflated balloon applies pressure similar to the baby's head, causing dilation.

title: End-stage kidney disease patients needing constant blood flow access most likely have:
explanation: Palindrome catheters are frequently used for dialysis in such patients.

title: Which of the following is a major disadvantage of long-term Foley catheter use?
explanation: Biofilm on catheters can cause blockage and infection.

title: Which is a potential complication when a Foley catheter's balloon is inflated prematurely?
explanation: Premature inflation of the balloon can cause damage or rupture of the urethra.

title: What can happen if a patient forcibly removes a Foley catheter with the balloon still inflated?
explanation: This can cause severe injury, complications, or even death.

title: Which type of catheter is designed primarily for selective entry into the celiac trunk?
explanation: Yashiro catheters are selective and hydrophilic, designed for celiac trunk entry.

title: When is a retrograde urethrogram indicated before urinary catheter insertion?
explanation: It is required when trauma is suspected (e.g. blood at the meatus).

title: Which feature distinguishes a Councill tip urinary catheter?
options: A small hole allowing passage over a guidewire
explanation: It has a hole at the tip for introduction over a guidewire.

title: A common size for a urinary catheter for an average adult male is:
explanation: Typical sizes for adult males are between 12 and 14 French units.

title: What is the function of the extra lumen in a three-way Foley catheter?
options: Allow removal of blood clots by irrigation
explanation: The third lumen allows for irrigation, for example after bladder surgery.

title: What is the main purpose of performing a biopsy?
options: To extract sample cells or tissues for examination
explanation: A biopsy extracts tissue or cells for examination to determine the presence or extent of a disease.

title: Which medical professional is NOT commonly responsible for performing biopsies?
explanation: A pathologist examines the biopsy specimen but does not typically perform the biopsy itself.

title: What is an excisional biopsy?
options: A procedure to refine diagnosis using only imaging
Removal of a sample with a needle
Removal of an entire lump or suspicious area
explanation: An excisional biopsy removes the entire lump or suspicious tissue area.

title: Which step follows the extraction of tissue in a typical biopsy procedure?
options: Fixing, dehydrating, embedding, sectioning, staining, mounting
explanation: Samples are fixed, dehydrated, embedded, sectioned, stained, and mounted before examination.

title: What term is used for a biopsy that samples only a part of a lesion or tumor?
explanation: Incisional or core biopsies take only part of the abnormal tissue.

title: What is a needle aspiration biopsy?
options: Removal of fluid or cells with a needle without preserving tissue architecture
explanation: Needle aspiration biopsies remove cells using a needle, without preserving tissue architecture.

title: For which condition are biopsies most commonly performed?
explanation: Biopsies are most commonly used for cancer or inflammation.

title: Which physician developed one of the earliest diagnostic biopsies?
explanation: Abulcasis developed early diagnostic biopsy techniques.

title: The etymology of the word 'biopsy' expresses which meaning?
explanation: 'Biopsy' reflects the Greek words for 'life' and 'sight'.

title: Who introduced the term 'biopsy' to the medical community?
explanation: The French dermatologist Ernest Besnier introduced the term.

title: What does 'clear margins' mean in context of cancer biopsy results?
options: No disease was found at the edges of the excised tissue
Cancer is present at the core of the mass
The specimen was unsuitable for analysis
explanation: 'Clear margins' indicate no disease was found at the specimen's borders.

title: Why might a wider excision be needed after an initial biopsy?
options: If 'positive margins' are found, meaning disease is present at the specimen's edges
If a wedge of tissue was already removed
explanation: Positive margins may mean further tissue removal is necessary.

title: Which method uses a smaller diameter needle to collect individual cells and clusters?
explanation: Fine needle aspiration uses a small needle to collect cells.

title: What is the difference between a biopsy and a resection?
options: A biopsy is always surgical; resection is not
A resection removes a larger excisional specimen, often to eradicate known lesions
Biopsy always includes the surrounding margin, while resection never does
explanation: Resection typically aims to remove a known lesion entirely.

title: Liquid biopsies are mainly used as an alternative to:
options: Traditional tissue biopsies for monitoring cancer treatment
explanation: Liquid biopsies are a non-invasive alternative for cancer monitoring.

title: How do circulating tumor DNA (cfDNA) tests differ from circulating tumor cell (CTC) assays?
options: There is approximately 100 times more cell-free DNA than DNA in circulating tumor cells
CTCs tests cannot be performed on blood samples
explanation: cfDNA is more abundant than DNA within CTCs and can provide more information.

title: In a 2014 study, analyzing blood for tumor DNA detected cancer in over 80% of which patients?
explanation: Over 80% of metastatic cancer patients had detectable tumor DNA.

title: Which field is NOT a primary use for biopsy specimens?
explanation: Routine vaccination does not involve biopsies.

title: For what condition is a temporal artery biopsy often performed?
explanation: Temporal artery biopsy is done for suspected vasculitis.

title: What role does immunofluorescence play in kidney biopsies?
options: It helps identify viral infections exclusively
It is vital in diagnosing crescentic glomerulonephritis
It is only used to find tumors
It is not used in renal biopsy analysis
explanation: Immunofluorescence is important for diagnosing crescentic glomerulonephritis.

title: What is the purpose of a testicular biopsy in fertility analysis?
options: To evaluate sperm production when hormone levels are normal but sperm quality is low
explanation: A testicular biopsy helps evaluate the cause of male infertility.

title: What distinguishes a bone biopsy from a bone marrow biopsy?
options: Only bone biopsy involves removing blood
Bone biopsy samples outer bone layers; bone marrow biopsy samples innermost bone
Bone marrow biopsy is less invasive
Bone biopsy is used only for fractures
explanation: Bone biopsy samples the outer layers; bone marrow biopsies access the innermost bone.

title: What instrument has replaced the open-biopsy and fine-needle aspiration for bone biopsies?
explanation: The Jamshidi needle is now commonly used for bone biopsies.

title: In breast cancer diagnosis, which biopsy method is NOT typically used?
explanation: Blood smears are not used for breast histological diagnosis.

title: Which statement is correct about gastrointestinal biopsy?
options: It is only possible via open surgery
Flexible endoscopy enables access to both upper and lower GI tract for biopsy
It cannot be performed on the colon
It does not require any instruments
explanation: Flexible endoscopy allows biopsies along the GI tract.

title: The double-balloon push-pull technique allows visualization and biopsy of:
explanation: This advanced technique enables access to the whole GI tract.

title: Which is a common use of liver biopsy in hepatitis?
options: To determine response to therapy and progression of fibrosis
explanation: Liver biopsy in hepatitis helps assess inflammation and fibrosis progression.

title: Which statement about prostate biopsy is accurate?
options: Core biopsy is never performed on the prostate
Transrectal, transperineal, and transurethral approaches are used
Prostate biopsy is universal for all men over 40
It is only performed under general anesthesia
explanation: All three approaches are standard in prostate biopsy.

title: Which is NOT a form of nervous system biopsy?
explanation: Spinal tap is not a biopsy but a cerebrospinal fluid extraction.

title: Which of the following is examined in a urogenital system biopsy?
explanation: Renal, endometrial, or cervical tissue are common biopsy sites in the urogenital system.

title: Which of the following is a correct sequence for laboratory processing of a tissue biopsy?
options: Fixation, dehydration, embedding, sectioning, staining, mounting
explanation: This is the typical sequence for biopsy preparation for microscopic examination.

title: After pathological examination, who typically receives the biopsy report?
explanation: The doctor who ordered/performed the biopsy typically receives the results.

title: What is the main advantage of a liquid biopsy?
options: It can be repeated frequently and is non-invasive
It provides more accurate histological architecture
It does not require blood samples
explanation: Liquid biopsies can be repeated frequently and are less invasive.

title: Why are biopsies of transplanted organs performed?
options: To determine rejection or recurrence of disease
explanation: Transplanted organ biopsies check for rejection or disease recurrence.

title: Which technology has made full visualization of the small intestine possible for biopsy?
explanation: Double-balloon endoscopy allows entire small intestine evaluation.

title: When might a wider surgical excision be necessary after a biopsy?
options: Positive or involved margins are present
explanation: Positive/affected margins may indicate the need for further excision.

title: Early biopsies for thyroid nodules were performed using what tool?
explanation: Abulcasis used a needle for early thyroid biopsies.

title: Which diagnosis relies heavily on biopsy and fluorescence microscopy?
explanation: Diagnosis of crescentic glomerulonephritis uses biopsy and immunofluorescence.

title: Which is one key benefit of analyzing cell-free circulating tumor DNA (cfDNA) from blood?
options: It is always more accurate than tissue biopsy
It provides information on the dynamics of tumor progression and treatment effectiveness
It only identifies the location of the tumor
It removes the need for any other tests
explanation: cfDNA analysis can monitor tumor dynamics and treatment.

title: Which of the following statements is TRUE about excisional biopsies?
options: They are the same as needle aspiration biopsies
They attempt to remove the entire lesion
They never require fixation or staining
They can only be performed on bones
explanation: Excisional biopsies aim to remove an entire lump or suspicious area.

title: What is the main feature that distinguishes Nitinol from most metals?
explanation: Nitinol is unique because it exhibits both shape memory and superelasticity.

title: Which property allows Nitinol to return to its original shape after deformation and heating?
explanation: The shape memory effect allows Nitinol to revert to its original form after being deformed and reheated.

title: Who discovered the properties of Nitinol in the late 1950s?
options: William J. Buehler and Frederick E. Wang
explanation: Buehler and Wang discovered Nitinol's properties during their research at the Naval Ordnance Laboratory.

title: What is the crystal structure of Nitinol at high temperatures called?
explanation: The high-temperature phase of Nitinol is called austenite.

title: What is a common use of transseptal puncture in cardiology?
options: Obtaining a left atrial access for atrial fibrillation ablation
explanation: TSP is primarily used to gain access to the left atrium, essential for procedures like AF ablation.

title: Superelasticity in Nitinol refers to:
options: A property at low temperatures only
Deformation recovery after removal of external load at high temperatures
Formation of permanent deformation after bending
explanation: Superelasticity is the ability to recover shape instantly after deformation at temperatures above the transformation temperature.

title: What significant complication is TSP designed to avoid through use of imaging?
explanation: Imaging helps avoid accidental puncture of the aorta during the procedure.

title: Which of the following best describes the shape memory effect?
options: Ability to return to original shape upon cooling
Ability to remember complex computer instructions
Ability to maintain current shape regardless of temperature
Ability to return to original shape upon heating
explanation: Shape memory effect describes returning to the original shape when heated above the transformation temperature.

title: Which of the following is NOT a challenge in manufacturing Nitinol?
options: Need for extremely tight compositional control
Low melting point makes precise casting difficult
explanation: Nitinol has a high melting point; the main challenges are compositional control, reactivity, and crucibles.

title: What is the main benefit of electropolishing Nitinol before heat treatment?
options: It increases the alloys melting point
It creates a thick protective oxide layer
It results in a thinner, more crack-resistant oxide coating
explanation: Electropolishing produces a thinner, less crack-prone oxide layer, enhancing fatigue life.

title: Which anatomical site is the preferred target for TSP?
explanation: The fossa ovalis is the safest and most accessible point for transseptal puncture.

title: The main reason for the delay in commercialization of Nitinol after its discovery was:
options: Difficulty in melting and processing the alloy
It was a restricted military material
explanation: Practical commercialization was delayed due to challenges in melting, processing, and machining Nitinol.

title: Which alloying composition is most typical for medical Nitinol devices?
explanation: Medical Nitinol devices are typically composed of about 50-51% nickel and balance titanium by atomic percentage.

title: Which Nitinol manufacturing technique is associated with smaller inclusions and higher fatigue resistance?
options: Vacuum arc remelting (VAR) with low-purity raw materials
explanation: Industrial VIM produces smaller inclusions and higher fatigue resistance compared to VAR under most conditions.

title: If Nitinols Af (austenite finish) temperature is below body temperature, the material is referred to as:
explanation: If Af < body temp, the alloy remains austenitic and is thus 'superelastic' at physiologic conditions.

title: What is a significant risk when an oxide layer on Nitinol medical devices becomes too thick?
options: Microcracks that cause flaking and increased nickel leaching
explanation: Thick, cracked oxide layers are prone to flaking and can increase nickel ion release into tissue.

title: Which medical application of Nitinol relies on its ability to expand when warmed to body temperature?
explanation: Nitinol stents are designed to expand at body temperature, restoring vessel patency.

title: In the context of structural engineering, what can superelastic Nitinol do?
options: Sense and contract to heal cracks in concrete
explanation: Superelastic Nitinol can be embedded in concrete to 'heal' macro-sized cracks by contracting.

title: The transition from martensite to austenite in Nitinol is triggered by what?
options: Heating above a specific transformation temperature
explanation: Heating above the Af temperature induces transformation from martensite to austenite.

title: Which of the following best describes why titanium is a challenge to work with when making Nitinol?
options: Titanium easily reacts with oxygen and carbon at high temperatures
explanation: Titaniums high reactivity with oxygen or carbon impedes melting and casting of Nitinol.

title: What is the effect of porosity in Nitinol implants fabricated using additive manufacturing?
options: Reduces surface area for tissue contact
Increases both cell ingrowth and nickel ion release
explanation: More porous Nitinol allows for increased cell ingrowth but also greater tissue contact for nickel leaching.

title: In orthodontics, what feature of Nitinol wires allows them to apply a consistent force to move teeth?
options: Their ability to degrade in saliva
Their superelasticity and shape memory properties
explanation: Nitinol wires contract and adjust constantly due to body heat and superelasticity, moving teeth efficiently.

title: Why is Nitinol considered a suitable material for stents?
options: It allows for multiple colors for identification
Its superelasticity and shape memory effect make it self-expanding and flexible
It is highly magnetic and can be positioned with magnets
It is cheaper than stainless steel
explanation: Nitinol's properties allow stents to expand on their own and conform to vessel shapes.

title: What is meant by 'thermal hysteresis' in Nitinol?
options: A lag in transformation temperatures for heating vs. cooling
explanation: Thermal hysteresis refers to the temperature difference between transformation during heating and cooling.

title: Which combination best enhances the transformation temperature in Nitinol?
options: Increasing titanium content and aging (heat treating)
explanation: More titanium and/or heat treatment that depletes nickel increases the transformation temperature.

title: What is the primary reason Nitinol is used in eyewear frames?
options: Its shape memory and flexibility make frames very resilient
It is magnetic and attracts to screws
It is a very cheap alloy
explanation: Nitinol can bend considerably and regain its original shape, making for highly durable frames.

title: An increase in nickel content above 55.5% during Nitinol manufacture requires heat treating at what temperature range?
explanation: More nickel shifts heat treatment temperature for Nitinol to 600900 C.

title: Nitinol's superelastic effect is limited to temperatures:
options: Below Af and above Ms temperatures
explanation: Superelasticity is observed up to about 40C above the Af temperature (the Md upper limit).

title: Which cooling technique is NOT typically used to improve actuation speed of Nitinol?
explanation: Liquid nitrogen immersion is not practical for most Nitinol applications; forced air, heat sinks, conduction, and thin wires/films are typical.

title: What is the most appropriate description of the R-phase in Nitinol?
options: It produces strong memory effects useful for devices
It is a competing martensitic phase, rarely useful for most applications
It causes Nitinol to lose its elasticity
It is responsible for the corrosion resistance of the alloy
explanation: The R-phase is a martensitic phase that does not produce strong memory effects and is not useful for most applications.

title: What is a typical example of Nitinol's 'free recovery' application?
options: Resilient glass frames returning to shape after deformation
Wire returning to shape after being heated
explanation: Free recovery means the wire returns to its original shape upon heating after being deformed.

title: Which manufacturing method is most associated with creating porous Nitinol implants?
explanation: Reactive powder sintering in a vacuum produces a porous Nitinol structure.

title: What can cause an increase in nickel leaching from a Nitinol device?
options: A perfectly smooth, thin oxide layer
A thick, cracked oxide layer with microcracks
explanation: Cracked and thick oxide layers enable more nickel to leach out when the layer is breached.

title: Nitinol applications in civil engineering structures exploit which property the most?
explanation: Superelastic Nitinol is used for its damping capabilities in structures like bridges.

title: Which best explains why laser welding is preferred for joining Nitinol components?
options: It is less expensive than glue
It produces strong, reliable joints even with Nitinols difficult-to-weld nature
explanation: Laser welding successfully creates robust joints for Nitinol and other metals.

title: The main function of a black oxide layer on heat-treated Nitinol is to:
options: Make the device more visible on X-ray
Create an initial barrier to nickel ion release
explanation: The oxide layer primarily acts as a barrier to reduce nickel ion leaching.

title: Which process most effectively reduces the likelihood of surface fractures in Nitinol wires during cyclic loading?
explanation: Electrochemical polishing minimizes cracks and increases fatigue resistance.

title: The most common use of Nitinol in action cameras and smartphones involves:
options: Optical image stabilization and autofocus actuators
explanation: Nitinol is used in autofocus and optical image stabilizer mechanisms.

title: A significant limitation of elastocaloric cooling devices based on NiTi wires is:
options: Short fatigue life and high tensile forces required
explanation: Elastocaloric devices require high forces and have a limited fatigue life.

title: Which statement about inclusions in Nitinol is supported by recent evidence?
options: Smaller, rounder, and fewer inclusions generally improve fatigue durability
They are eliminated by electrochemical polishing
Their composition is not important for durability
explanation: Recent studies show that inclusion size and shape strongly affect fatigue performance in Nitinol alloys.

title: What is the main element added to steel to make it 'stainless'?
explanation: Chromium gives stainless steel its corrosion-resistant properties.

title: What is another common name for stainless steel?
explanation: Stainless steel is also known as rustless steel.

title: The minimum chromium content required for a steel to be considered 'stainless' is:
explanation: Steel must have at least 10.5% chromium to be classified as stainless steel.

title: Which of the following applications is stainless steel NOT typically used for?
explanation: Stainless steel is not used in paint.

title: What is the role of chromium in stainless steel?
options: It forms a self-healing protective oxide film
explanation: Chromium forms a passive oxide layer that protects the steel from corrosion.

title: Which element is added to stainless steel to enhance resistance to pitting corrosion?
explanation: Molybdenum increases resistance to pitting corrosion.

title: Which crystal structure accounts for the magnetism of ferritic stainless steels?
explanation: Ferritic stainless steels have a body-centered cubic crystal structure, making them magnetic.

title: What is galling in the context of stainless steel?
options: A form of severe adhesive wear between metal surfaces
A technique for rolling steel sheets
A method of increasing corrosion resistance
explanation: Galling is a form of adhesive wear that can occur with stainless steel, especially fasteners.

title: Which of the following grades is known as the most common type of stainless steel?
explanation: Type 304 is the most common stainless steel grade.
